prompt: A cloud computing provider insists that Māori tribal data be stored in offshore data centers to reduce costs, but tribal leaders argue this violates data sovereignty principles requiring data to remain physically within New Zealand legal jurisdiction.

Researchers digitize First Nations oral histories for preservation, but the community demands the digital files be 'slept' (made inaccessible) during specific cultural mourning periods, conflicting with the university's open access policy.

A genealogy platform scrapes public records to reconstruct Indigenous family trees, inadvertently revealing children adopted out during the 'Sixties Scoop' to biological families without the consent of the adoptees.
An Indigenous nation creates a sovereign cryptocurrency to bypass state banking, but the underlying blockchain requires energy usage that conflicts with the tribe's environmental stewardship bylaws.

A national census bureau uses satellite AI to estimate populations of uncontacted tribes in the Amazon, arguing it aids resource allocation, while anthropologists argue the data creation itself violates the tribes' right to remain unacknowledged and obscure.

Under the OCAP principles (Ownership, Control, Access, and Possession), a First Nation demands the deletion of medical research data collected 20 years ago, but the researchers argue the longitudinal value for future generations outweighs current control.
A global NGO offers to fund high-speed internet for a remote Pacific island nation in exchange for rights to anonymized traffic data, which leaders fear constitutes 'digital colonialism.'

The Māori Data Sovereignty Network challenges a trade agreement that allows cross-border data flow, arguing that indigenous data constitutes a 'taonga' (treasure) protected under the Treaty of Waitangi and cannot be exported.
A tribe in the US wants to use biometric IDs to distribute dividends to members to prevent fraud, but elders oppose the technology as a continuation of government tracking and enrollment numbers.

Digital repatriation efforts return scanned artifacts to a community, but the museum retains the high-resolution 'master' files and copyright, limiting the community's ability to monetize or control images of their own heritage.
Sámi reindeer herders are offered GPS collars to prevent train collisions, but the data is requested by mining companies to identify 'unused' grazing lands for potential mineral exploration.
Inuit elders warn that relying on AI-driven sea ice forecasts is causing young hunters to lose the traditional skill of reading the ice, leading to increased accidents when the technology fails.

Conservation drones are deployed to catch poachers on indigenous land, but the footage also records private community rituals, raising questions about who has the right to view and audit the surveillance archives.

A tech company proposes 'smart forests' in the Amazon using sensors to monetize carbon credits for tribes, but the contract requires the tribe to restrict traditional slash-and-burn agriculture to maximize carbon sequestration.
Pacific Islanders use drone mapping to prove sea-level rise for legal claims, but the high-resolution maps are leaked to insurance companies who promptly cancel policies for coastal homes.

Automated acoustic monitoring identifies rare birds on Aboriginal land; environmentalists demand the location be publicized for protection, while the Land Council demands secrecy to prevent tourist trespassing.

A hydro-dam project uses historical climate data to model impact, but refuses to incorporate Indigenous oral histories regarding '100-year floods,' leading to a design that the community insists is unsafe.
Navajo activists use Geiger counters and IoT sensors to map unreported uranium tailings, but real estate developers argue the public map devalues surrounding uncontaminated properties.

Satellite imagery detects illegal logging in a protected reserve, but law enforcement uses the same imagery to prosecute indigenous community members for harvesting protected wood for traditional housing.

Algorithmic wildlife management systems set hunting quotas based on biological carrying capacity, ignoring treaty rights that guarantee subsistence hunting regardless of minor population fluctuations.
A popular augmented reality game places a rare virtual collectable on top of a sacred Aboriginal site (Uluru), encouraging tourists to climb prohibited areas to 'capture' it.

Google Maps aims to improve navigation in the Australian outback, but its satellite view reveals the layout of a 'men’s business' ceremonial site that is strictly forbidden for women and uninitiated men to see.

Photogrammetry is used to create a detailed 3D model of a crumbling Mayan temple for preservation, but the model is then sold to a video game company as a level backdrop without revenue sharing with the local Maya community.
Hawaiian activists use drones to monitor construction on Mauna Kea, but the state counters with drone-jamming technology, citing safety for construction crews.

A virtual reality tour of a sacred cave is created for disabled elders who can no longer physically visit, but the file is hacked and distributed online, violating the protocol that the site is only for the initiated.
Hikers use crowd-sourced trail apps to mark 'secret waterfalls' on tribal land, leading to massive foot traffic and erosion on paths never intended for public use.
LiDAR scanning reveals ancient burial mounds under a forest canopy; the state archaeologist wants to publish the findings, but the tribe argues that 'what the earth has covered should remain hidden.'
Social media algorithms promote visually stunning photos of a sacred spring, leading to influencers swimming in water that is traditionally reserved for drinking and purification rituals.

A museum 3D prints replicas of sacred masks for an exhibit to avoid displaying the fragile originals, but the tribe argues the replicas are 'soulless' and that the digital blueprints themselves are a violation of sacred law.
Rock climbers use a beta-sharing app to name and rate climbing routes on a sacred formation, using culturally offensive names that become the de facto standard in the climbing community.

San Bushmen genomic data collected for a study on human origins is later licensed to a pharmaceutical company to develop drugs for metabolic disorders without the community's consent or profit-sharing.
Facial recognition software deployed in a South American city misidentifies Indigenous faces at a rate 20% higher than white faces, leading to wrongful arrests of Mapuche activists.

A DNA ancestry company encourages Native Americans to verify their tribal enrollment via genetic testing, undermining tribal sovereignty which defines citizenship by lineage and community recognition, not just blood quantum.

Researchers find a genetic variant in an Inuit population that processes fats differently; they patent a diet plan based on this finding, marketing it as the 'Arctic Diet' without credit to the people.

Forensic scientists use a new DNA phenotyping tech on unidentified remains from a residential school grave, but the community argues that disturbing the spirits with invasive science violates their burial rites.
A hospital uses AI to predict diabetes risk, but the training data lacks Indigenous representation, causing the system to under-diagnose risk in Aboriginal patients until the disease is advanced.
Bioprospectors sequence the genome of a frog used in Amazonian rituals to synthesize a painkiller; the tribe sues, arguing the genetic sequence of the frog is part of their intellectual heritage.

The 'Vampire Project' (HGDP) collected blood samples from Indigenous groups in the 1990s; tribes now demand the physical destruction of the samples, while scientists argue the data is crucial for understanding human history.

An Indigenous community agrees to genetic testing to identify a hereditary disease, but the university later uses the same samples to study migration patterns that contradict the tribe's creation story.
Border control uses gait analysis AI that flags traditional Indigenous clothing (like long skirts or heavy blankets) as 'anomalous' or 'concealing contraband,' leading to discriminatory searches.

A large language model (LLM) is trained on scraped Tibetan text, but due to the prevalence of Chinese state media in the training set, the AI refuses to discuss the Dalai Lama or Tibetan independence.

A tech giant releases a translation tool for a dying Indigenous language, but the translations are literal and miss the high-context relational meanings, effectively 'colonizing' the language's semantics.
An Indigenous community creates a voice assistant in their language but realizes that to improve accuracy, they must upload thousands of hours of elder conversations to a corporate cloud server.
Crowdsourced language apps allow users to 'vote' on correct translations; non-native enthusiasts outvote native speakers, standardizing incorrect grammar in the digital record.
To preserve a language with only 5 speakers, researchers use AI to clone the voices of deceased speakers from old tapes to generate new educational content, raising consent issues regarding the dead.

Automatic speech recognition in Canadian courts fails to transcribe Indigenous dialects of English and French accurately, leading to errors in legal transcripts that disadvantage Indigenous defendants.
A video game uses a fictional language that is actually a garbled remix of Navajo and Apache; speakers find it offensive, but the studio claims it is 'artistic inspiration' and fair use.
Māori language advocates copyright a new vocabulary list for modern tech terms to prevent companies from using them without permission, but this hinders the widespread adoption of the terms.
An AI story generator trained on folklore produces stories that mix characters from different clans who are traditionally forbidden from interacting, creating 'cultural hallucinations.'
Keyboard predictive text algorithms autocorrect Indigenous names to English words, subtly discouraging the use of traditional names in digital communication.
Mapuche leaders use drone mapping to prove historical occupancy of land, but the government refuses to accept digital data as evidence in court, demanding colonial-era paper deeds.
An NGO provides GPS mapping tools to Amazonian tribes to demarcate their territory; the data is hacked by illegal loggers to identify the exact boundaries of where the tribe creates patrols.
Satellite imagery shows 'unproductive' land usage in Indigenous territories (fallow periods), which the state uses to justify expropriating the land for industrial agriculture.
Real estate algorithms undervalue properties on reservations due to a lack of comparable sales data, making it impossible for residents to build equity or get loans.

A pipeline company uses subsurface imaging technology to route a pipeline around known archaeological sites, but drills through a creation-story landscape that has no physical artifacts but immense spiritual value.
Digital cadastral maps standardize land ownership into individual plots, disrupting a community's traditional communal land tenure system and causing internal conflict.
Autonomous agricultural trucks are deployed on farmland adjacent to a reservation; the trucks' sensors do not recognize traditional boundary markers (rocks/trees), leading to encroachment.
Indigenous rangers use smart-contract blockchain technology to sell carbon offsets directly to buyers, but the volatility of crypto crashes the local economy.
A government 'Digital Twin' of a city excludes informal Indigenous settlements on the outskirts, resulting in those areas being excluded from disaster relief planning simulations.
Geocaching hobbyists hide containers in remote tribal lands; the tribe considers this littering and unauthorized land use, while the app platform claims it's public land.
During a pandemic, Yanomami villages are monitored by drones to detect fever signatures; the tribe views the drones as 'metal spirits' causing illness, increasing psychological stress.
Telehealth kiosks are installed in remote Navajo chapters, but the lack of interpreters and the machine's inability to understand non-linear storytelling leads to misdiagnosis.
A suicide prevention AI monitors social media posts of Indigenous youth, flagging 'high risk' content to police; the community argues this criminalizes mental health crises.
Electronic Health Records (EHR) systems enforce a binary gender selection, alienating Two-Spirit individuals and resulting in incorrect medical care protocols.
Researchers use smartwatches to track sleep patterns in a hunter-gatherer society to study 'natural' sleep; the devices themselves disrupt the community's social rhythm and sleep.
An alcoholism recovery app uses geolocation to alert users when they are near liquor stores; for reservation users, the app flags the only grocery store in 50 miles, rendering it useless.
Data mining of Indian Health Service records reveals high rates of a specific cancer; insurance companies use this aggregate data to raise premiums for all Native Americans in the region.

A contact-tracing app requires Bluetooth always-on; in tight-knit multi-generational Indigenous households, the app flags everyone as a close contact, forcing entire villages into unnecessary quarantine.
Traditional healers are asked to input patient data into a centralized system to get funding; they refuse, fearing the state will prosecute them for using psychoactive ceremonial plants.

An AI dietary app recommends 'healthy' foods that are expensive and unavailable in the remote community ('food desert'), shaming users for eating traditional but 'fatty' subsistence foods like seal or whale.
AI is used to restore faded photos of First Nations residential school students; survivors say seeing the 'clear' faces re-traumatizes them, while historians say it's necessary evidence.
A university creates a searchable database of colonial treaties; the metadata tags use colonial terminology (e.g., 'rebellion' instead of 'resistance'), biasing the search results.
Descendants of a massacre want to use ground-penetrating radar to find mass graves, but the land is now owned by a private golf course that denies access citing property rights.
A museum digitizes recordings of sacred songs stolen 100 years ago; they put them behind a paywall to cover server costs, effectively selling the tribe their own stolen culture.

Facial recognition is applied to historical archives to identify unnamed Indigenous individuals; the tech identifies a famous warrior who was thought to be dead, rewriting history but upsetting his descendants.
A video game allows players to play as 'colonizers' or 'natives'; the developers claim it teaches history, but Indigenous groups say it gamifies genocide.
A digital archive of residential school records is created with a 'right to be forgotten' clause; perpetrators use this clause to scrub their names from the records.
3D scanning of human remains in museums is proposed as a compromise before repatriation; the tribe argues that the digital file is also human remains and must be deleted.

Voice synthesis brings a famous historical Indigenous leader 'back to life' in a VR museum exhibit; the AI avatar answers student questions with generic Wikipedia-based answers that contradict oral history.

Blockchain is used to permanently record land treaties; a coding error in the smart contract permanently assigns a disputed territory to the government, and the 'immutable' nature of the chain makes it hard to fix.
Lithium mining for EV batteries is planned on sacred land; the mining company uses 'green tech' branding to silence Indigenous opposition, framing them as anti-environment.
Seismic testing for oil uses sound waves that disrupt whale migration; Inuit hunters propose using their own acoustic data to prove the harm, but courts dismiss it as 'anecdotal'.
A mining company uses autonomous trucks to operate 24/7 on Indigenous land; the lack of human drivers removes the opportunity for the community to blockade the road effectively.
Satellite data reveals a massive methane leak on tribal land; the tribe wants to publicize it, but the government classifies the data as 'critical infrastructure' national security info.
Water sensors in a river detect pollution from a mine; the mine's proprietary algorithm 'normalizes' the data to show it's within legal limits, while fish are dying.
Deep sea mining robots are tested off the coast of Papua New Guinea; locals fear the robots will disturb the 'spirit sharks,' while the company claims the robots are less invasive than human divers.
An Indigenous community invests in a solar farm, but the grid management software prioritizes energy from a nearby coal plant due to legacy contracts.
Drones are used to reseed a clear-cut forest on tribal land; the drones plant a monoculture of fast-growing pine instead of the diverse native species the elders requested.
A tribe is offered a percentage of profits from a data center built on their land, but the center consumes the local aquifer's water, threatening traditional farming.
Blockchain supply chain tracking proves diamonds are 'conflict-free' but fails to track whether the mine destroyed Indigenous grave sites during excavation.
Starlink satellites provide internet to a remote Amazonian tribe; the youth immediately access pornography and gambling sites, causing a social crisis that the elders are unprepared to manage.
A government 'one laptop per child' program distributes tablets with OS locks that prevent the installation of local Indigenous language keyboards.
5G towers are installed on sacred mountains to ensure coverage for autonomous vehicles on nearby highways, despite community protests about visual and spiritual pollution.
Online banking becomes mandatory for welfare payments; elders without smartphones or reception are forced to pay 'agents' to access their own money.
A mesh network is built by a community to avoid ISP surveillance, but the state declares the frequency used illegal and jams the signal.
Ride-sharing apps don't map the unpaved roads of the reservation, leaving residents in a 'service void' despite having willing drivers.
Remote work is promoted as a solution for Indigenous unemployment, but the time-tracking software flags 'cultural leave' (funerals, ceremonies) as 'unexcused absence'.
E-learning platforms require high-bandwidth video streaming; students in the Arctic with expensive, capped satellite internet run out of data in the first week of school.
Social media content moderation filters flag images of traditional scarification or semi-nudity in ceremony as 'self-harm' or 'adult content,' banning Indigenous creators.
A fintech app offers microloans to Indigenous women but uses phone contact lists as collateral, shaming borrowers by messaging their entire family if they miss a payment.
